<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article uses a <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgian</a> surname: the surname is <a href="/wiki/Carton_de_Wiart" title="Carton de Wiart">Carton de Wiart</a>, not Wiart.</div>

<p><a href="/wiki/Lieutenant-general_(United_Kingdom)" title="Lieutenant-general (United Kingdom)">Lieutenant-General</a> <b>Sir Adrian Paul Ghislain Carton de Wiart</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> <span class="noexcerpt nowraplinks" style="font-size:100%; font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Victoria_Cross" title="Victoria Cross">VC</a><span style="font-size:14px;">&#44;</span>&#32;<a href="/wiki/Knight_Commander_of_the_Order_of_the_British_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire">KBE</a><span style="font-size:14px;">&#44;</span>&#32;<a href="/wiki/Companion_of_the_Order_of_the_Bath" class="mw-redirect" title="Companion of the Order of the Bath">CB</a><span style="font-size:14px;">&#44;</span>&#32;<a href="/wiki/Companion_of_the_Order_of_St_Michael_and_St_George" class="mw-redirect" title="Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George">CMG</a><span style="font-size:14px;">&#44;</span>&#32;<a href="/wiki/Distinguished_Service_Order" title="Distinguished Service Order">DSO</a></span> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="&#39;d&#39; in &#39;dye&#39;">d</span><span title="/É™/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">É™</span></span><span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="&#39;w&#39; in &#39;wind&#39;">w</span><span title="/aÉª/: &#39;i&#39; in &#39;tide&#39;">aÉª</span><span title="/./: syllable break">.</span><span title="/É™r/: &#39;er&#39; in &#39;letter&#39;">É™r</span><span title="&#39;t&#39; in &#39;tie&#39;">t</span></span>/</a></span></span>;<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> 5 May 1880 â€“ 5 June 1963) was a <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British Army</a> officer born of Belgian and Irish parents. He was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Cross" title="Victoria Cross">Victoria Cross</a>, the highest military decoration awarded for valour "in the face of the enemy" in various Commonwealth countries.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> He served in the <a href="/wiki/Boer_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Boer War">Boer War</a>, <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">First World War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Second_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Second World War">Second World War</a>. He was shot in the face, head, stomach, ankle, leg, hip, and ear; was blinded in his left eye; survived two plane crashes; tunnelled out of a <a href="/wiki/Prisoner-of-war_camp" title="Prisoner-of-war camp">prisoner-of-war camp</a>; and tore off his own fingers when a doctor declined to amputate them. Describing his experiences in the First World War, he wrote, "Frankly I had enjoyed the war."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195089_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195089-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After returning home from service (including a period as a prisoner-of-war) in the <a href="/wiki/Second_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Second World War">Second World War</a>, he was sent to China as <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>'s personal representative. While <i>en route</i> he attended the <a href="/wiki/Cairo_Conference_(1943)" class="mw-redirect" title="Cairo Conference (1943)">Cairo Conference</a>.
</p><p>In his memoirs, Carton de Wiart wrote, "Governments may think and say as they like, but force cannot be eliminated, and it is the only real and unanswerable power. We are told that <a href="/wiki/The_pen_is_mightier_than_the_sword" title="The pen is mightier than the sword">the pen is mightier than the sword</a>, but I know which of these weapons I would choose."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950271_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950271-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Carton de Wiart was thought to be a model for the character of Brigadier Ben Ritchie-Hook in <a href="/wiki/Evelyn_Waugh" title="Evelyn Waugh">Evelyn Waugh</a>'s trilogy <i><a href="/wiki/Sword_of_Honour" title="Sword of Honour">Sword of Honour</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_Dictionary_of_National_Biography" class="mw-redirect" title="Oxford Dictionary of National Biography">Oxford Dictionary of National Biography</a></i> described him thus: "With his black eyepatch and empty sleeve, Carton de Wiart looked like an elegant pirate, and became a figure of legend."<sup id="cite_ref-ODNB_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODNB-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Background">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Carton de Wiart was born into an <a href="/wiki/Aristocracy_(class)" title="Aristocracy (class)">aristocratic</a> family in <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a>, on 5 May 1880, eldest son of LÃ©on Constant Ghislain Carton de Wiart (1854â€“1915) and Ernestine Wenzig (1860â€“1886). By his contemporaries, he was widely believed to be an illegitimate son of <a href="/wiki/Leopold_II_of_the_Belgians" class="mw-redirect" title="Leopold II of the Belgians">King Leopold II of the Belgians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> He spent his early days in Belgium and in England.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart19505_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart19505-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> The 'loss of his mother' when he was six prompted his father to move the family to <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> so his father could practise at Egypt's <a href="/wiki/Mixed_Courts_of_Egypt" title="Mixed Courts of Egypt">mixed courts</a>. It was widely assumed by biographers that his mother had died in 1886; however, his parents had in fact divorced in that year and his mother remarried Demosthenes Gregory Cuppa later in 1886.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> His father was a lawyer and magistrate, as well as a <a href="/wiki/Board_of_directors" title="Board of directors">director</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Cairo_Electric_Railways_and_Heliopolis_Oases_Company" title="Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oases Company">Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oases Company</a> and was well connected in Egyptian governmental circles. Adrian Carton de Wiart learned to speak <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195012_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195012-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Carton de Wiart was a <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholic</a>. In 1891, his English stepmother sent him to a <a href="/wiki/Boarding_school" title="Boarding school">boarding school</a> in England, the Roman Catholic <a href="/wiki/The_Oratory_School" title="The Oratory School">Oratory School</a>, founded by <a href="/wiki/John_Henry_Newman" title="John Henry Newman">John Henry Newman</a>. From there, he went to <a href="/wiki/Balliol_College,_Oxford" title="Balliol College, Oxford">Balliol College, Oxford</a>, but left to join the British Army at the time of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Boer_War" title="Second Boer War">Second Boer War</a> around 1899, where he entered under the false name of "Trooper Carton", claiming to be 25 years old. His real age was no more than 20.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_Boer_War">Second Boer War</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Second Boer War">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Carton de Wiart was wounded in the stomach and groin in South Africa early in the Second Boer War and was invalided home. His father was furious when he learned his son had abandoned his studies, but allowed his son to remain in the army. After another brief period at Oxford, where <a href="/wiki/Aubrey_Herbert" title="Aubrey Herbert">Aubrey Herbert</a> was among his friends, he was given a commission in the Second <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Light_Horse" class="mw-redirect" title="Imperial Light Horse">Imperial Light Horse</a>. He saw action in South Africa again, and on 14 September 1901 was given a regular commission as a second lieutenant in the <a href="/wiki/4th_Dragoon_Guards" class="mw-redirect" title="4th Dragoon Guards">4th Dragoon Guards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> Carton de Wiart was transferred to India in 1902. He enjoyed sports, especially shooting and <a href="/wiki/Boar_hunting" title="Boar hunting">pig sticking</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195027_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195027-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_1904.jpg" class="image"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_1904.jpg/220px-Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_1904.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="324" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_1904.jpg/330px-Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_1904.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_1904.jpg/440px-Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_1904.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1980" data-file-height="2920" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_1904.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Carton de Wiart as a <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_(British_Army_and_Royal_Marines)" title="Lieutenant (British Army and Royal Marines)">lieutenant</a> with the <a href="/wiki/4th_Dragoon_Guards" class="mw-redirect" title="4th Dragoon Guards">4th Dragoon Guards</a> at <a href="/wiki/Mathura" title="Mathura">Muttra</a> in September 1904</div></div></div>
<h2><span id="Character.2C_interests_and_life_in_the_Edwardian_army"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Character,_interests_and_life_in_the_Edwardian_army">Character, interests and life in the Edwardian army</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Character, interests and life in the Edwardian army">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Carton de Wiart's serious wound in the Boer War instilled in him a strong desire for physical fitness and he ran, jogged, walked, and played sports on a regular basis. In male company he was "a delightful character and must hold the world record for bad language."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERanfurly1995123_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERanfurly1995123-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After his regiment was transferred to South Africa he was promoted to supernumerary <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_(British_Army_and_Royal_Marines)" title="Lieutenant (British Army and Royal Marines)">lieutenant</a> on 16 July 1904 and appointed an <a href="/wiki/Aide-de-camp" title="Aide-de-camp">aide-de-camp</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-Chief" class="mw-redirect" title="Commander-in-Chief">Commander-in-Chief</a>, Sir <a href="/wiki/Henry_Hildyard" title="Henry Hildyard">Henry Hildyard</a>, the following July.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> He describes this period lasting up to 1914 as his "Heyday", the title of Chapter 3 of his autobiography. His light duties as aide-de-camp gave him time for <a href="/wiki/Polo" title="Polo">polo</a>, another of his interests.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195027_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195027-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> By 1907, although Carton de Wiart had now served in the British Army for eight years, he had remained a Belgian subject. On 13 September of that year, he took the oath of allegiance to <a href="/wiki/Edward_VII" title="Edward VII">Edward VII</a> and was formally naturalised as a British subject.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1908 he married Countess Friederike Maria Karoline Henriette Rosa Sabina Franziska <a href="/wiki/Fugger_family" title="Fugger family">Fugger von Babenhausen</a> (1887 <a href="/wiki/Klagenfurt" title="Klagenfurt">Klagenfurt</a> â€“ 1949 <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Vienna</a>), eldest daughter of Karl, 5th <a href="/wiki/F%C3%BCrst" title="FÃ¼rst">FÃ¼rst</a> (Prince) von Fugger-Babenhausen and <a href="/wiki/Princess_Eleonora_Fugger_von_Babenhausen" title="Princess Eleonora Fugger von Babenhausen">Princess Eleonora zu Hohenlohe-Bartenstein und Jagstberg</a> of Klagenfurt, Austria. They had two daughters, the elder of whom Anita (born 1909, deceased) was the maternal grandmother of the war correspondent <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Loyd" title="Anthony Loyd">Anthony Loyd</a> (born 1966).<sup id="cite_ref-name_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-name-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Carton de Wiart was already well connected in European circles, his two closest cousins being Count <a href="/wiki/Henri_Carton_de_Wiart" class="mw-redirect" title="Henri Carton de Wiart">Henri Carton de Wiart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Belgium" title="Prime Minister of Belgium">Prime Minister of Belgium</a> from 1920 to 1921, and Baron Edmond Carton de Wiart, political secretary to the King of Belgium and director of <a href="/wiki/Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale_de_Belgique" title="SociÃ©tÃ© GÃ©nÃ©rale de Belgique">La SociÃ©tÃ© GÃ©nÃ©rale de Belgique</a>. While on leave, he travelled extensively throughout central Europe, using his Catholic aristocratic connections to shoot at country estates in <a href="/wiki/Bohemia" title="Bohemia">Bohemia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bavaria" title="Bavaria">Bavaria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195042_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195042-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> Following his return to England, he rode with the famous <a href="/wiki/Duke_of_Beaufort%27s_Hunt" title="Duke of Beaufort&#39;s Hunt">Duke of Beaufort's Hunt</a> where he met, among others, the future field marshal, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Maitland_Wilson" title="Henry Maitland Wilson">Sir Henry Maitland Wilson</a>, and the future <a href="/wiki/Air_marshal" title="Air marshal">air marshal</a>, Sir <a href="/wiki/Edward_Ellington" title="Edward Ellington">Edward Ellington</a>. He was promoted to <a href="/wiki/Captain_(British_Army_and_Royal_Marines)" title="Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)">captain</a> on 26 February 1910.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Henry_Somerset,_9th_Duke_of_Beaufort" title="Henry Somerset, 9th Duke of Beaufort">Duke of Beaufort</a> was the honorary colonel of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Gloucestershire_Hussars" title="Royal Gloucestershire Hussars">Royal Gloucestershire Hussars</a>, and from 1 January 1912 until his departure for Somaliland in 1914 Carton de Wiart served as the regiment's <a href="/wiki/Adjutant" title="Adjutant">adjutant</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFox192350,_54,_57_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFox192350,_54,_57-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="First_World_War">First World War</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: First World War">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Somaliland_Campaign">Somaliland Campaign</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Somaliland Campaign">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>When the First World War broke out, Carton de Wiart was en route to <a href="/wiki/British_Somaliland" title="British Somaliland">British Somaliland</a> where a <a href="/wiki/Somaliland_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Somaliland Campaign">low-level war</a> was underway against the followers of Dervish leader <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Abdullah_Hassan" title="Mohammed Abdullah Hassan">Mohammed bin Abdullah</a>, called the "Mad Mullah" by the British. Carton de Wiart had been seconded to the <a href="/wiki/Somaliland_Camel_Corps" title="Somaliland Camel Corps">Somaliland Camel Corps</a>. A staff officer with the corps was <a href="/wiki/Hastings_Ismay" class="mw-redirect" title="Hastings Ismay">Hastings Ismay</a>, later Lord Ismay, Churchill's military advisor.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195050_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195050-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> In an attack upon an enemy fort at <a href="/wiki/Shimber_Berris" class="mw-redirect" title="Shimber Berris">Shimber Berris</a>, Carton de Wiart was shot twice in the face, losing his eye and also a portion of his ear. He was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Distinguished_Service_Order" title="Distinguished Service Order">Distinguished Service Order</a> (DSO) on 15 May 1915.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Western_Front">Western Front</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Western Front">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In February 1915, he embarked on a <a href="/wiki/Steamship" title="Steamship">steamer</a> for France. Carton de Wiart took part in the fighting on the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western Front</a>, commanding successively three infantry battalions and a brigade. He was wounded seven more times in the war, losing his left hand in 1915 and pulling off his fingers when a doctor declined to remove them.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> He was shot through the skull and ankle at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Battle of the Somme</a>, through the hip at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Passchendaele" title="Battle of Passchendaele">Battle of Passchendaele</a>, through the leg at <a href="/wiki/Cambrai" title="Cambrai">Cambrai</a>, and through the ear at <a href="/wiki/Arras,_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Arras, France">Arras</a>. He went to the Sir Douglas Shield's Nursing Home to recover from his injuries.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195054_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195054-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Victoria_Cross">Victoria Cross</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Victoria Cross">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Carton de Wiart received the <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Cross" title="Victoria Cross">Victoria Cross</a> (VC), the highest award for gallantry in combat that can be awarded to <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> forces, in 1916. He was 36 years old, and a temporary <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant-colonel" class="mw-redirect" title="Lieutenant-colonel">lieutenant-colonel</a> in the <a href="/wiki/4th_Royal_Irish_Dragoon_Guards" title="4th Royal Irish Dragoon Guards">4th Dragoon Guards (Royal Irish)</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British Army</a>, attached to the <a href="/wiki/Gloucestershire_Regiment" title="Gloucestershire Regiment">Gloucestershire Regiment</a>, commanding the 8th Battalion, when the following events took place on 2/3 July 1916 at <a href="/wiki/La_Boiselle" class="mw-redirect" title="La Boiselle">La Boiselle</a>, France, as recorded in the official citation:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote">
<p>Capt. (temp. Lt.-Col.) Adrian Carton de Wiart, D.S.O., Dn. Gds.
</p><p>
For most conspicuous bravery, coolness and determination during severe operations of a prolonged nature. It was owing in a great measure to his dauntless courage and inspiring example that a serious reverse was averted. He displayed the utmost energy and courage in forcing our attack home. After three other battalion Commanders had become casualties, he controlled their commands, and ensured that the ground won was maintained at all costs. He frequently exposed himself in the organisation of positions and of supplies, passing unflinchingly through fire barrage of the most intense nature. His gallantry was inspiring to all.</p><div class="templatequotecite">â€”&#8201;<cite><i>London Gazette</i>, 9 September 1916.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceF_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceF-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote>
<p>His Victoria Cross is displayed at the <a href="/wiki/National_Army_Museum" title="National Army Museum">National Army Museum</a>, Chelsea.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1916.E2.80.931918"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1916â€“1918">1916â€“1918</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: 1916â€“1918">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Carton de Wiart was promoted to temporary major in March 1916.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> He subsequently attained the rank of temporary lieutenant colonel on 18 July, was <a href="/wiki/Brevet_(military)" title="Brevet (military)">brevetted</a> to major on 1 January 1917 and was promoted to temporary <a href="/wiki/Brigadier_general" title="Brigadier general">brigadier general</a> on 12 January 1917.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> He was appointed an <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Crown_(Belgium)" title="Order of the Crown (Belgium)">Officer of the Order of the Crown</a> of Belgium in April 1917.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> On 3 June 1917, Carton de Wiart was brevetted to lieutenant-colonel.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> On 18 July, he was promoted to the substantive rank of major in the Dragoon Guards.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> He was awarded the Belgian <a href="/wiki/Croix_de_guerre_(Belgium)" title="Croix de guerre (Belgium)">Croix de Guerre</a> in March 1918,<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceD_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceD-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup> and was appointed a <a href="/wiki/Companion_of_the_Order_of_St_Michael_and_St_George" class="mw-redirect" title="Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George">Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George</a> in the King's Birthday Honours List in June.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceE_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceE-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Three days before the end of the war, on 8 November, Carton de Wiart was given command of a brigade with the rank of temporary brigadier general.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> A S Bullock gives a vivid first-hand description of his arrival: 'Cold shivers went down the back of everyone in the brigade, for he had an unsurpassed record as a fire eater, missing no chance of throwing the men under his command into whatever fighting happened to be going.' Bullock recalls how the battalion looked 'very much the worse for wear' when they paraded for the brigadier general's inspection. He arrived 'on a lively cob with his cap tilted at a rakish angle, and a shade over the place where one of his eyes had been'. He was also missing two limbs and had eleven wound stripes. Bullock, the first man in line for the inspection, notes that Carton de Wiart, despite having only one eye, ordered him to get his bootlace changed.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Post_First_World_War_era_and_the_Polish_mission">Post First World War era and the Polish mission</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Post First World War era and the Polish mission">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sir_Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_by_Sir_William_Orpen.jpg" class="image"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Sir_Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_by_Sir_William_Orpen.jpg/250px-Sir_Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_by_Sir_William_Orpen.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="323" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Sir_Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_by_Sir_William_Orpen.jpg/375px-Sir_Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_by_Sir_William_Orpen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Sir_Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_by_Sir_William_Orpen.jpg/500px-Sir_Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_by_Sir_William_Orpen.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2400" data-file-height="3099" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sir_Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart_by_Sir_William_Orpen.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Painting by <a href="/wiki/William_Orpen" title="William Orpen">Sir William Orpen</a>, 1919 (<a href="/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery,_London" title="National Portrait Gallery, London">National Portrait Gallery, London</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>At the end of the war Carton de Wiart was sent to <a href="/wiki/Second_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Second Republic of Poland">Poland</a> as second in command of the <a href="/wiki/British_Military_Mission_to_Poland" title="British Military Mission to Poland">British-Poland Military Mission</a> under General <a href="/wiki/Louis_Botha" title="Louis Botha">Louis Botha</a>. Carton de Wiart was appointed a <a href="/wiki/Companion_of_the_Order_of_the_Bath" class="mw-redirect" title="Companion of the Order of the Bath">Companion of the Order of the Bath</a> in the 1919 King's Birthday Honours List.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceG_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceG-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> After a brief period, he replaced General Botha in the mission to Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195092_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart195092-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Poland desperately needed support, as it was engaged with <a href="/wiki/Bolshevik_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolshevik Russia">Bolshevik Russia</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Polish-Soviet_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish-Soviet War">Polish-Soviet War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukrainians</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Polish-Ukrainian_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish-Ukrainian War">Polish-Ukrainian War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuanians</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Polish-Lithuanian_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish-Lithuanian War">Polish-Lithuanian War</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovakia" title="Czechoslovakia">Czechs</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Border_conflicts_between_Poland_and_Czechoslovakia" class="mw-redirect" title="Border conflicts between Poland and Czechoslovakia">Czech-Polish border conflicts</a>. There he met <a href="/wiki/Ignacy_Jan_Paderewski" title="Ignacy Jan Paderewski">Ignacy Jan Paderewski</a>, the pianist and premier, Marshal <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski" title="JÃ³zef PiÅ‚sudski">JÃ³zef PiÅ‚sudski</a>, the Chief of State and military commander, and General <a href="/wiki/Maxime_Weygand" title="Maxime Weygand">Maxime Weygand</a>, head of the <a href="/wiki/French_military_mission_to_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="French military mission to Poland">French military mission</a> in mid-1920.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950106_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950106-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> One of his tasks soon after his arrival was to attempt to make peace between the Poles and the Ukrainian nationalists under <a href="/wiki/Simon_Petlyura" class="mw-redirect" title="Simon Petlyura">Simon Petlyura</a>. The Ukrainians were besieging the city of <a href="/wiki/Lw%C3%B3w" class="mw-redirect" title="LwÃ³w">LwÃ³w</a> (<span title="Ukrainian-language text"><i lang="uk">Lvov</i></span>; <span title="German-language text"><i lang="de">Lemberg</i></span>). The discussions were unsuccessful.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>From there he went on to Paris to report on Polish conditions to the British Prime Minister, <a href="/wiki/David_Lloyd_George" title="David Lloyd George">David Lloyd George</a> and to General <a href="/wiki/Sir_Henry_Wilson,_1st_Baronet" title="Sir Henry Wilson, 1st Baronet">Sir Henry Wilson</a>. Lloyd George was not sympathetic to Poland and, much to Carton de Wiart's annoyance, Britain sent next to no military supplies. Then he went back to Poland and many more front line adventures, this time in the Bolshevik zone, where the situation was grave and Warsaw threatened. During this time he had significant interaction with the <a href="/wiki/Nuntius" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuntius">nuntius</a> (dean of the Vatican diplomatic corps) Cardinal Achille Ratti, later <a href="/wiki/Pius_XI" class="mw-redirect" title="Pius XI">Pius XI</a>, who wanted Carton de Wiart's advice as to whether to evacuate the diplomatic corps from Warsaw. The diplomats moved to <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84" title="PoznaÅ„">PoznaÅ„</a>, but the Italians remained in Warsaw along with Ratti.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950108_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950108-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>From all these affairs, Carton de Wiart developed a sympathy with the Poles and supported their claims to eastern <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Central_Europe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Galicia (Central Europe)">Galicia</a>. This caused disagreement with Lloyd George at their next meeting, but was appreciated by the Poles. At one time during his Warsaw stay he was a second in a duel between Polish members of the Mysliwski Club, the other second being Baron <a href="/wiki/Carl_Gustaf_Emil_Mannerheim" title="Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim">Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim</a>, later commander-in-chief of Finnish armies in World War II and President of Finland. <a href="/wiki/Norman_Davies" title="Norman Davies">Norman Davies</a> reports that he was "compromised in a gun-running operation from <a href="/wiki/Budapest" title="Budapest">Budapest</a> using stolen wagon-lits".<sup id="cite_ref-Davies2011_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davies2011-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>He became close to the Polish leader, Marshal PiÅ‚sudski. After an aircraft crash occasioning a brief period in Lithuanian captivity, he went back to England to report, this time to the <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_War" title="Secretary of State for War">Secretary of State for War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>. He passed on to Churchill PiÅ‚sudski's prediction that the <a href="/wiki/White_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="White Movement">White Russian</a> offensive under General <a href="/wiki/Anton_Denikin" title="Anton Denikin">Anton Denikin</a> directed at Moscow would fail. It did shortly thereafter. Churchill was more sympathetic to Polish needs than Lloyd George and succeeded, over Lloyd George's objections, in sending some <a href="/wiki/Materiel" title="Materiel">materiel</a> to Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 27 July 1920, Carton de Wiart was appointed an <a href="/wiki/Aide-de-camp" title="Aide-de-camp">aide-de-camp</a> to the king, and brevetted to <a href="/wiki/Colonel_(United_Kingdom)" title="Colonel (United Kingdom)">colonel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> He was active in August 1920, when the <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> were at the gates of Warsaw. While out on his observation train, he was attacked by a group of Red cavalry, and fought them off with his revolver from the footplate of his train, at one point falling on the track and re-boarding quickly.<sup id="cite_ref-day_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-day-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>When the Poles won the war, the British Military Mission was wound up. Carton de Wiart was promoted to temporary brigadier general and also appointed to the local rank of <a href="/wiki/Divisional_general" title="Divisional general">major general</a> on 1 January.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> He was promoted to the substantive rank of colonel on 21 June 1922, with seniority from 27 July 1920 and relinquished his local rank of major general on 1 April 1923, going on half-pay as a colonel at the same time.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> Carton de Wiart officially retired from the army on 19 December, with the honorary rank of <a href="/wiki/Major-general_(United_Kingdom)" title="Major-general (United Kingdom)">major general</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Polish_gentleman_.281924.E2.80.931939.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Polish_gentleman_(1924â€“1939)">Polish gentleman (1924â€“1939)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Polish gentleman (1924â€“1939)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>His last Polish aide de camp was <a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karol_Miko%C5%82aj_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82" class="extiw" title="pl:Karol MikoÅ‚aj RadziwiÅ‚Å‚">Prince Karol MikoÅ‚aj RadziwiÅ‚Å‚</a>, member of the <a href="/wiki/Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82_family" title="RadziwiÅ‚Å‚ family">RadziwiÅ‚Å‚ family</a> who inherited a large 500,000-acre (200,000&#160;ha) estate in eastern Poland when the communists killed his uncle. They became friends and Carton de Wiart was given the use of a large estate called ProstyÅ„, in the <a href="/wiki/Pripet_Marshes" class="mw-redirect" title="Pripet Marshes">Pripet Marshes</a>, a wetland area larger than <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> and surrounded by water and forests.<sup id="cite_ref-day_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-day-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> In this location Carton de Wiart spent the rest of the interwar years. In his memoirs he said "In my fifteen years in the marshes I did not waste one day without hunting".<sup id="cite_ref-day_47-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-day-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After 15 years, Carton de Wiart's peaceful Polish life was interrupted by the looming war, when he was recalled in July 1939 and appointed to his old job, as head of the <a href="/wiki/British_Military_Mission_to_Poland" title="British Military Mission to Poland">British Military Mission to Poland</a>. <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">Poland was attacked</a> by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> on 1 September and on 17 September the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviets</a> <a href="/wiki/Nazi-Soviet_Alliance" class="mw-redirect" title="Nazi-Soviet Alliance">allied with Germany</a> attacked Poland <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland" title="Soviet invasion of Poland">from the east</a>. Soon Soviet forces overran ProstyÅ„ and Carton de Wiart lost all his guns, fishing rods, clothing, and furniture. They were packed up by the Soviets and stored in the <a href="/wiki/Minsk#Museums" title="Minsk">Minsk Museum</a>, but destroyed by the Germans in later fighting. He never saw the area again, but as he said "they did not manage to take my memories".<sup id="cite_ref-day_47-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-day-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_World_War">Second World War</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Second World War">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cecil_Beaton_Photographs-_Political_and_Military_Personalities;_Carton_de_Wiart,_Adrian_IB3449C.jpg" class="image"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Cecil_Beaton_Photographs-_Political_and_Military_Personalities%3B_Carton_de_Wiart%2C_Adrian_IB3449C.jpg/250px-Cecil_Beaton_Photographs-_Political_and_Military_Personalities%3B_Carton_de_Wiart%2C_Adrian_IB3449C.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="263" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Cecil_Beaton_Photographs-_Political_and_Military_Personalities%3B_Carton_de_Wiart%2C_Adrian_IB3449C.jpg/375px-Cecil_Beaton_Photographs-_Political_and_Military_Personalities%3B_Carton_de_Wiart%2C_Adrian_IB3449C.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Cecil_Beaton_Photographs-_Political_and_Military_Personalities%3B_Carton_de_Wiart%2C_Adrian_IB3449C.jpg/500px-Cecil_Beaton_Photographs-_Political_and_Military_Personalities%3B_Carton_de_Wiart%2C_Adrian_IB3449C.jpg 2x" data-file-width="760" data-file-height="800" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Cecil_Beaton_Photographs-_Political_and_Military_Personalities;_Carton_de_Wiart,_Adrian_IB3449C.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Adrian Carton de Wiart during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, photographed by <a href="/wiki/Cecil_Beaton" title="Cecil Beaton">Cecil Beaton</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span id="Polish_campaign_.281939.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Polish_campaign_(1939)">Polish campaign (1939)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Polish campaign (1939)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Carton de Wiart met with the Polish <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marshal_of_Poland" title="Marshal of Poland">Marshal of Poland</a> <a href="/wiki/Edward_Rydz-%C5%9Amig%C5%82y" title="Edward Rydz-ÅšmigÅ‚y">Edward Rydz-ÅšmigÅ‚y</a>, in late August 1939 and formed a rather low opinion of his capabilities. He strongly urged Rydz-ÅšmigÅ‚y to pull Polish forces back beyond the <a href="/wiki/Vistula_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Vistula River">Vistula River</a>, but was unsuccessful.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950158_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950158-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> The other advice he offered, to have the seagoing units of the Polish fleet leave the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>, was, after much argument, <a href="/wiki/Peking_Plan" title="Peking Plan">finally adopted</a>. This fleet made a <a href="/wiki/Polish_contribution_to_World_War_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish contribution to World War II">significant contribution to the Allied cause</a>, especially the several modern destroyers and submarines.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950155_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950155-53">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As Polish resistance weakened, Carton de Wiart evacuated his mission from Warsaw along with the Polish government. Together with the Polish commander Rydz-ÅšmigÅ‚y, Carton de Wiart made his way with the rest of the British Mission to the Romanian border with both the Germans and the Soviets in pursuit. His car convoy was attacked by the <a href="/wiki/Luftwaffe" title="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a> on the road, and the wife of one of his <a href="/wiki/Aide-de-camp" title="Aide-de-camp">aides</a> was killed. He was in danger of arrest in Romania and got out by aircraft on 21 September with a false passport, just in time as the pro-Allied Romanian prime minister, <a href="/wiki/Armand_Calinescu" class="mw-redirect" title="Armand Calinescu">Armand Calinescu</a>, was assassinated that day.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Norwegian_campaign_.281940.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Norwegian_campaign_(1940)">Norwegian campaign (1940)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Norwegian campaign (1940)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Namsos_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Namsos Campaign">Namsos Campaign</a></div>
<p>Recalled to a special appointment in the army in the autumn of 1939, Carton de Wiart reverted to his former rank of colonel. He was granted the rank of acting major general on 28 November.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> After a brief stint in command of the <a href="/wiki/61st_Infantry_Division_(United_Kingdom)" title="61st Infantry Division (United Kingdom)">61st Division</a> in the English Midlands, Carton de Wiart was summoned in April 1940 to take charge of a hastily drawn together Anglo-French force to occupy <a href="/wiki/Namsos_(town)" title="Namsos (town)">Namsos</a>, a small town in middle Norway. His orders were to take the city of <a href="/wiki/Trondheim" title="Trondheim">Trondheim</a>, 125 miles (200&#160;km) to the south, in conjunction with a naval attack and an advance from the south by troops landed at <a href="/wiki/%C3%85ndalsnes" title="Ã…ndalsnes">Ã…ndalsnes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950168_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950168-56">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> He flew to Namsos to reconnoitre the location before the troops arrived. When his <a href="/wiki/Short_Sunderland" title="Short Sunderland">Short Sunderland</a> flying boat landed, it was attacked by a German fighter and his aide was wounded and had to be evacuated. After the <a href="/wiki/Chasseurs_Alpins" title="Chasseurs Alpins">French Alpine troops</a> landed<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950169_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950169-57">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> (without their transport mules and missing straps for their skis), the Luftwaffe bombed and destroyed the town of Namsos.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_British_Army_in_Norway_April_-_June_1940_N107.jpg" class="image"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/The_British_Army_in_Norway_April_-_June_1940_N107.jpg/220px-The_British_Army_in_Norway_April_-_June_1940_N107.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/The_British_Army_in_Norway_April_-_June_1940_N107.jpg/330px-The_British_Army_in_Norway_April_-_June_1940_N107.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/The_British_Army_in_Norway_April_-_June_1940_N107.jpg/440px-The_British_Army_in_Norway_April_-_June_1940_N107.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="610" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_British_Army_in_Norway_April_-_June_1940_N107.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>British soldiers on the quay at Namsos awaiting evacuation from Norway. On the left is Major General Carton de Wiart.</div></div></div>
<p>Despite these handicaps, Carton de Wiart managed to move his forces over the mountains and down to <a href="/wiki/Trondheimsfjord" class="mw-redirect" title="Trondheimsfjord">Trondheimsfjord</a>, where they were shelled by German destroyers. They had no artillery to challenge the German ships. It soon became apparent that the whole Norwegian campaign was fast becoming a failure. The naval attack on Trondheim, the reason for the Namsos landing, did not happen and his troops were exposed without guns, transport, air cover, or skis in a foot and a half of snow. They were being attacked by German ski troops, machine gunned and bombed from the air, and the German Navy was landing troops to his rear. He recommended withdrawal but was asked to hold his position for political reasons, which he did.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950174_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950174-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After orders and counterorders from London, the decision to evacuate was made. However, on the date set to evacuate the troops, the ships did not appear. The next night a naval force finally arrived, led through the fog by <a href="/wiki/Lord_Louis_Mountbatten" class="mw-redirect" title="Lord Louis Mountbatten">Lord Louis Mountbatten</a>. The transports successfully evacuated the entire force amid heavy bombardment by the Germans, resulting in the sinking of two <a href="/wiki/Destroyer" title="Destroyer">destroyers</a>: the French <a href="/wiki/French_destroyer_Bison_(1928)" title="French destroyer Bison (1928)"><i>Bison</i></a> and British <a href="/wiki/HMS_Afridi_(F07)" title="HMS Afridi (F07)">HMS&#160;<i>Afridi</i></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950174_59-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950174-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> Carton de Wiart arrived back at the British naval base of <a href="/wiki/Scapa_Flow" title="Scapa Flow">Scapa Flow</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Orkney_Islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Orkney Islands">Orkney Islands</a> on 5 May 1940, his 60th birthday.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950174_59-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950174-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Northern_Ireland">Northern Ireland</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Northern Ireland">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Carton de Wiart was posted back to the command of the 61st Division, which was soon transferred to <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> as a defence against invasion.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950176_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950176-60">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> However, following the arrival of Lieutenant-General <a href="/wiki/Henry_Pownall" title="Henry Pownall">Sir Henry Pownall</a> as Commander-in-Chief in Northern Ireland, Carton de Wiart was told that he was too old to command a division on active duty.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950178_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950178-61">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="British_military_mission_to_Yugoslavia_.281941.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="British_military_mission_to_Yugoslavia_(1941)">British military mission to Yugoslavia (1941)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: British military mission to Yugoslavia (1941)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia_and_the_Allies" title="Yugoslavia and the Allies">Yugoslavia and the Allies</a></div>
<p>Advanced to temporary major-general on 28 November 1940,<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> he remained inactive very briefly, as he was appointed as head of the <a href="/wiki/British_Military_Mission_to_Yugoslavia" class="mw-redirect" title="British Military Mission to Yugoslavia">British-Yugoslavian Military Mission</a> on 5 April 1941. Hitler was preparing to invade the country and the Yugoslavs asked for British help. Carton de Wiart travelled in a <a href="/wiki/Vickers_Wellington" title="Vickers Wellington">Vickers Wellington</a> bomber to <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">Belgrade, Serbia</a> to negotiate with the Yugoslavian government. After refuelling in Malta,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950179_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950179-63">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> the aircraft left for Cairo with enemy territory to the north and south. Both engines failed off the coast of <a href="/wiki/Italian_Libya" title="Italian Libya">Italian-controlled Libya</a>, and the plane crash-landed in the sea about a mile from land. Carton de Wiart was knocked unconscious, but the cold water made him regain consciousness. When the plane broke up and sank, he and the rest aboard were forced to swim to shore.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950180_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950180-64">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup> They were captured by the Italian authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950181_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950181-65">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Prisoner_of_war_in_Italy_.281941.E2.80.931943.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Prisoner_of_war_in_Italy_(1941â€“1943)">Prisoner of war in Italy (1941â€“1943)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Prisoner of war in Italy (1941â€“1943)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Carton de Wiart was a high-profile prisoner. After four months at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Villa_Orsini&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Villa Orsini (page does not exist)">Villa Orsini</a> at <a href="/wiki/Sulmona" title="Sulmona">Sulmona</a>, he was transferred to a special prison for senior officers at <a href="/wiki/Vincigliata" title="Vincigliata">Castello di Vincigliata</a>. There were a number of senior officer prisoners here due to the successes achieved by <a href="/wiki/Erwin_Rommel" title="Erwin Rommel">Rommel</a> in North Africa early in 1941. Carton de Wiart made friends, especially with General <a href="/wiki/Sir_Richard_O%27Connor" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir Richard O&#39;Connor">Sir Richard O'Connor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Knox,_6th_Earl_of_Ranfurly" title="Daniel Knox, 6th Earl of Ranfurly">The 6th Earl of Ranfurly</a> and Lieutenant-General <a href="/wiki/Philip_Neame" title="Philip Neame">Philip Neame</a>, VC.
In letters to his wife, Lord Ranfurly described Carton de Wiart in captivity as "a delightful character" and said he "must hold the record for bad language." Ranfurly was "endlessly amused by him. He really is a nice person â€“ superbly outspoken."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERanfurly1995123_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERanfurly1995123-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> The four were committed to escaping. He made five attempts, including seven months tunnelling. Once Carton de Wiart evaded capture for eight days disguised as an Italian peasant (he was in northern Italy, could not speak Italian, and was 62 years old, with an eye patch, one empty sleeve and multiple injuries and scars).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950213_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950213-66">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Then, in a surprising development, Carton de Wiart was taken from prison in August 1943 and driven to Rome. The Italian government was secretly planning to leave the war and wanted Carton de Wiart to send the message to the British Army about a peace treaty with the UK. Carton de Wiart was to accompany an Italian negotiator, General <a href="/w/index.php?title=Giacomo_Zanussi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Giacomo Zanussi (page does not exist)">Giacomo Zanussi</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;&#91;<a href="https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giacomo_Zanussi" class="extiw" title="it:Giacomo Zanussi">it</a>&#93;</span>, to Lisbon to meet Allied contacts to negotiate the surrender. To keep the mission secret, Carton de Wiart was told he needed civilian clothes. Distrusting Italian tailors, he stated that "[he] had no objection provided [he] did not resemble a <a href="/wiki/Gigolo" title="Gigolo">gigolo</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950226_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950226-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> In <i>Happy Odyssey</i>, he described the resultant suit as being "as good as anything that ever came out of <a href="/wiki/Savile_Row" title="Savile Row">Savile Row</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950226_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950226-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> When they reached Lisbon, Carton de Wiart was released and made his way to England, reaching there on 28 August 1943.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950230_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950230-68">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="China_mission_.281943.E2.80.931947.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="China_mission_(1943â€“1947)">China mission (1943â€“1947)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: China mission (1943â€“1947)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CairoConferenceParticipants.jpg" class="image"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/CairoConferenceParticipants.jpg/300px-CairoConferenceParticipants.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="224" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/CairoConferenceParticipants.jpg/450px-CairoConferenceParticipants.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/CairoConferenceParticipants.jpg/600px-CairoConferenceParticipants.jpg 2x" data-file-width="805" data-file-height="600" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:CairoConferenceParticipants.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Carton de Wiart in the <a href="/wiki/Cairo_Conference" title="Cairo Conference">Cairo Conference</a>, behind <a href="/wiki/Soong_Mei-ling" title="Soong Mei-ling">Soong Mei-ling</a> on the right. From left to right: <a href="/wiki/Generalissimo" title="Generalissimo">Generalissimo</a> <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a>, US President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt" class="mw-redirect" title="Franklin Delano Roosevelt">Franklin Delano Roosevelt</a>, British Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soong_Mei-ling" title="Soong Mei-ling">Soong Mei-ling</a>. Back row, Chinese Generals Chang Chen and Ling Wei; American Generals Somervell, Stilwell and Arnold; and senior British officers, Field Marshal Sir <a href="/wiki/John_Dill" title="John Dill">John Dill</a>, Admiral <a href="/wiki/Lord_Louis_Mountbatten" class="mw-redirect" title="Lord Louis Mountbatten">Lord Louis Mountbatten</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Within a month of his arrival back in England, Carton de Wiart was summoned to spend a night at the prime minister's country home at <a href="/wiki/Chequers" title="Chequers">Chequers</a>. Churchill informed him that he was to be sent to <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912â€“1949)">China</a> as his personal representative. He was granted the rank of acting lieutenant-general on 9 October,<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> and left by air for India on 18 October 1943. <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations" title="Chinaâ€“United Kingdom relations">Anglo-Chinese relations</a> were difficult in World War II as the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> had long called for the end of British <a href="/wiki/Concessions_in_China" title="Concessions in China">extraterritorial rights in China</a> together with the return of Hong Kong, neither proposal being welcome to Churchill. In early 1942, Churchill had to ask <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a> to send Chinese troops to help the British hold Burma from the Japanese, and following the Japanese conquest of Burma the <a href="/wiki/X_Force" title="X Force">X Force</a> of five Chinese divisions had ended up in eastern India.<sup id="cite_ref-Fenby,_Jonathan_page_373_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fenby,_Jonathan_page_373-70">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> Churchill was unhappy with having the X Force defend India as it weakened the prestige of the Raj, and in an attempt to improve relations with China, the prime minister felt a soldier experienced in diplomacy such as Carton de Wiart would be the best man to be his personal representative in China.<sup id="cite_ref-Fenby,_Jonathan_page_373_70-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fenby,_Jonathan_page_373-70">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As his accommodation in China was not ready, Carton de Wiart spent time in India gaining an understanding of the situation in China, especially being briefed by a genuine <i><a href="/wiki/Tai-pan" title="Tai-pan">tai-pan</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Keswick_family" title="Keswick family">John Keswick</a>, head of the great China trading empire <a href="/wiki/Jardine_Matheson" title="Jardine Matheson">Jardine Matheson</a>. He met the Viceroy, Field Marshal Viscount <a href="/wiki/Archibald_Wavell" class="mw-redirect" title="Archibald Wavell">Wavell</a> and General Sir <a href="/wiki/Claude_Auchinleck" title="Claude Auchinleck">Claude Auchinleck</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-Chief,_India" title="Commander-in-Chief, India">Commander-in-Chief in India</a>. He also met <a href="/wiki/Orde_Wingate" title="Orde Wingate">Orde Wingate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950237_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950237-71">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> Before arriving in China, Carton de Wiart attended the <a href="/wiki/Cairo_Conference_(1943)" class="mw-redirect" title="Cairo Conference (1943)">1943 Cairo Conference</a> organized by Churchill, U.S President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt" class="mw-redirect" title="Franklin Delano Roosevelt">Roosevelt</a> and Chinese Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950239_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950239-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>When in Cairo, he took the opportunity to renew his acquaintance with <a href="/wiki/Hermione,_Countess_of_Ranfurly" title="Hermione, Countess of Ranfurly">Hermione, Countess of Ranfurly</a>, the wife of his friend from prisoner-of-war days, Dan Ranfurly. Carton de Wiart was one of the few to be able to work with the notoriously difficult commander of US forces in the China-Burma-India Theatre, U.S Army General <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stilwell" title="Joseph Stilwell">Joseph Stilwell</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950240_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950240-73">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> He arrived in the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Nationalist Chinese Government</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chungking" class="mw-redirect" title="Chungking">Chungking</a> (Chongqing), in early December 1943. For the next three years, he was to be involved in a host of reporting, diplomatic and administrative duties in the remote wartime capital. Carton de Wiart became a great admirer of the Chinese people. He wrote that, when he was appointed as Churchill's personal representative to Chiang Kai-shek in China, he imagined a country "full of whimsical little people with quaint customs who carved lovely jade ornaments and worshiped their grandmothers."<sup id="cite_ref-Fenby,_Jonathan_page_373_70-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fenby,_Jonathan_page_373-70">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> Once stationed in China, however, he wrote: "Two things struck me forcibly: the first was the amount of sheer hard work the people were doing, and the second their cheerfulness in doing it."<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:British_Generals_1939-1945_A20588.jpg" class="image"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/British_Generals_1939-1945_A20588.jpg/250px-British_Generals_1939-1945_A20588.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="326" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/British_Generals_1939-1945_A20588.jpg/375px-British_Generals_1939-1945_A20588.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/British_Generals_1939-1945_A20588.jpg/500px-British_Generals_1939-1945_A20588.jpg 2x" data-file-width="613" data-file-height="800" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:British_Generals_1939-1945_A20588.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Carton de Wiart in Cairo, 1943.</div></div></div>
<p>He regularly flew out to India to liaise with British officials. His old friend, Richard O'Connor, had escaped from the Italian prisoner-of-war camp and was now in command of British troops in eastern India. The <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Governor of Bengal">Governor of Bengal</a>, the Australian <a href="/wiki/Richard_Casey,_Baron_Casey" title="Richard Casey, Baron Casey">Richard Casey</a>, became a good friend.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 9 October 1944, Carton de Wiart was promoted to temporary <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant-General_(United_Kingdom)" class="mw-redirect" title="Lieutenant-General (United Kingdom)">lieutenant-general</a> and to the war substantive rank of major-general.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> Carton de Wiart returned home in December 1944 to report to the <a href="/wiki/War_Cabinet" class="mw-redirect" title="War Cabinet">War Cabinet</a> on the Chinese situation. He was appointed <a href="/wiki/Knight_Commander_of_the_Order_of_the_British_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire">Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire</a> (KBE) in the <a href="/wiki/1945_New_Year_Honours" title="1945 New Year Honours">1945 New Year Honours</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceH_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceH-77">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Clement_Attlee" title="Clement Attlee">Clement Attlee</a>, when he became head of the Labour Government in June 1945, asked Carton de Wiart to stay on in China.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950273_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950273-78">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="South_East_Asia">South East Asia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: South East Asia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Carton de Wiart was assigned to a tour of the Burma Front, and after meeting Admiral Sir <a href="/wiki/James_Somerville_(admiral)" class="mw-redirect" title="James Somerville (admiral)">James Somerville</a>, Commander-in-Chief of the <a href="/wiki/British_Eastern_Fleet" class="mw-redirect" title="British Eastern Fleet">British Eastern Fleet</a>, he was given a front seat on the bridge of the battleship <a href="/wiki/HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_(1913)" title="HMS Queen Elizabeth (1913)">HMS&#160;<i>Queen Elizabeth</i></a> for the bombardment of Sabang in the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_East_Indies" class="mw-redirect" title="Netherlands East Indies">Netherlands East Indies</a> in 1945, including air battles between Japanese fighters and British carrier aircraft.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Admiral_of_the_Fleet_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma_SE3547.jpg" class="image"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Admiral_of_the_Fleet_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma_SE3547.jpg/220px-Admiral_of_the_Fleet_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma_SE3547.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="217" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Admiral_of_the_Fleet_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma_SE3547.jpg/330px-Admiral_of_the_Fleet_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma_SE3547.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Admiral_of_the_Fleet_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma_SE3547.jpg/440px-Admiral_of_the_Fleet_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma_SE3547.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="789" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Admiral_of_the_Fleet_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma_SE3547.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Supreme Allied Commander South East Asia: Mountbatten with General Chiang Kai-Shek (left) and Dr T V Soong (right). In the background are Captain R V Brockman, Lt Gen F A M Browning and General Carton de Wiart VC at Chungking.</div></div></div>
<p>A good part of Carton de Wiart's reporting had to do with the increasing power of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communists" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese Communists">Chinese Communists</a>. The journalist and historian <a href="/wiki/Max_Hastings" title="Max Hastings">Max Hastings</a> writes: "De Wiart despised all Communists on principle, denounced <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> as 'a fanatic', and added: 'I cannot believe he means business'. He told the British cabinet that there was no conceivable alternative to Chiang as ruler of China."<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> He met Mao Zedong at dinner and had a memorable exchange with him, interrupting his propaganda speech to criticise him for holding back from fighting the Japanese for domestic political reasons. Mao was briefly stunned, and then laughed.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950270_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950270-81">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After the Japanese surrender in August 1945, Carton de Wiart flew to Singapore to participate in the formal surrender. After a visit to <a href="/wiki/Peking" class="mw-redirect" title="Peking">Peking</a>, he moved to <a href="/wiki/Nanking" class="mw-redirect" title="Nanking">Nanking</a>, the now-liberated Nationalist capital, accompanied by <a href="/wiki/Julian_Amery" title="Julian Amery">Julian Amery</a>, the British Prime Minister's Personal Representative to Chiang.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> A visit to <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> to meet General <a href="/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur" title="Douglas MacArthur">Douglas MacArthur</a> came at the end of his tenure. He was now 66 and ready to retire, despite the offer of a job by Chiang. Carton de Wiart retired in October 1947, with the honorary rank of lieutenant-general.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Retirement_and_death">Retirement and death</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Retirement and death">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>En route home via <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a>, Carton de Wiart stopped in <a href="/wiki/Rangoon" class="mw-redirect" title="Rangoon">Rangoon</a> as a guest of the army commander. Coming down stairs, he slipped on coconut matting, fell down, broke several vertebrae, and knocked himself unconscious. He was admitted to <a href="/wiki/Yangon_General_Hospital" title="Yangon General Hospital">Rangoon Hospital</a> where he was treated.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950282_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarton_de_Wiart1950282-84">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> His wife died in 1949. In 1951, at the age of 71, he married Ruth Myrtle Muriel Joan McKechnie, a divorcee known as Joan Sutherland, 23 years his junior (born in late 1903, she died 13 January 2006 at the age of 102.)<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup> They settled at <a href="/wiki/Aghinagh_House" title="Aghinagh House">Aghinagh House</a>, Killinardrish, <a href="/wiki/County_Cork" title="County Cork">County Cork</a>, Ireland.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Carton de Wiart died at the age of 83 on 5 June 1963. He left no papers.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> He and his wife Joan are buried in Caum Churchyard just off the main Macroom road. The grave site is just outside the actual graveyard wall on the grounds of his own home, Aghinagh House. Carton de Wiart's will was valued at <a href="/wiki/Probate" title="Probate">probate</a> in Ireland at Â£4,158 and in England at Â£3,496.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Publications">Publications</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Publications">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><i>Happy Odyssey: The Memoirs of Lieutenant-General Sir Adrian Carton de Wiart</i>, Jonathan Cape, 1950.</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_decorations">Awards and decorations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Awards and decorations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Carton de Wiart was the recipient of several awards:<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="In_popular_culture">In popular culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Carton_de_Wiart&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: In popular culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Carton de Wiart is the subject of the 2022 song "The Unkillable Soldier" by Swedish heavy metal band <a href="/wiki/Sabaton_(band)" title="Sabaton (band)">Sabaton</a> on their album <i><a href="/wiki/The_War_to_End_All_Wars_(album)" title="The War to End All Wars (album)">The War to End all Wars</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
